Award.AwardTitle: Instrument Development and Data Analysis for LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
The next few years will be very exciting in gravitational wave physics. In 2015-18, the Advanced LIGO detectors will produce data in the first Observing Runs, with increasing sensitivity and likelihood of the first direct detection of the gravitational waves predicted by Einstein's theory of General Relativity. The expected first detected signals will be from neutron stars coalescing to form a black hole, a cataclysmic astrophysical event. Other possible signals from the coalescence of two black holes into a larger one, and from the merging of a neutron star and a black hole, would lead to great astronomical insights of the existence and features of black holes in the Universe. This group's activities focus on aspects of improvement of the Advanced LIGO detectors and the characterization of data from the Advanced LIGO interferometer. These efforts are fully integrated with those of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC), and are especially integrated with the activities of the LIGO Livingston Observatory, since that Observatory is located only 30 miles from the LSU campus.

The LSU group will pursue research activities in two main topics, all coordinated with the LSC and key to the detection of gravitational waves with the Advanced LIGO detectors. One is detector improvement: diagnosing and improving the detector's noise spectral density, data quality and instrument artifacts; calibration of the detector, including error budget and cross validation with different methods; environmental monitoring and effect mitigation; and diagnosing and reduction of transients in suspended test masses. The second is the characterization of the detectors' data: identifying and vetoing instrumental artifacts; developing quantitative statistical methods to use the result of "follow up investigations" of gravitational wave candidates to measure confidence in their astrophysical nature, and reduce the possibility that they may be due to rare instrumental artifacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the LSU group for the improvement of the sensitivity of the LIGO detectors in Hanford, Washington and Livingston, Louisiana, as well as for the characterization and calibration of the data obtained with the instruments. The work was done in collaboration with the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC). During most of the duration of this award, Gabriela Gonzalez was the LSC spokesperson and leader. 

With the continued support of NSF to LIGO and the LSC in the US (including our group), the first gravitational waves were detected on September 14, 2015, originated in the collision of two black holes more than a billion light years away. The announcement was made on February 11, 2016 and became world-wide news; Gonzalez (as LSC spokesperson) was one of the scientists making the announcement in the NSF press conference Washington DC. 

Following the first detection, there were two others in the First Observing Run in 2015-2016, seven other detections from black hole mergers in the Second Observing Run in 2016-2017, and the first observation from the collision of neutron stars in August 17, 2017. The electromagnetic waves emitted by this event was observed by many telescopes around the world and some in space. The evidence collected helped to understand the nuclear science happening in the stars’ collision, which is involved in creation of heavy elements like gold and platinum. 

The LSU group was a significant contributor to achieving the LIGO detectors sensitivity that allowed the detections, to the diagnosis of the noise sources in the instrument, to the calibration of the detector’s output and to data characterization used to validate the gravitational wave events and reduce the false positives. 

This award has supported the formation of very creative graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, and has fostered diversity in the STEM workforce. The LSU group supported by this award has had 4-7 people, about 50% female, with two Hispanic and an African American member. A female postdoc is now working as permanent staff in a national laboratory, another female PhD is now a faculty member, another female PhD will start a fellowship at NASA. The whole group has been involved in the dissemination of the discoveries to the general public in pubic talks and staffing open house activities at the LIGO Science Education Center.
